Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Romeo and Juliet in education curriculum across schools worldwide:

## Romeo and Juliet in Global Education Curricula

Romeo and Juliet is commonly taught in 9th grade English curricula, and it appears as a key text in various educational systems worldwide.

### Educational Implementation Worldwide

Cambridge University Press provides educational materials that unlock the potential of millions of people worldwide, with assessments, publications and research that spread knowledge around the world. They offer Romeo and Juliet South African School Edition specifically designed for educational use.

In the UK, Romeo and Juliet is part of the AQA GCSE English Literature exam curriculum, and there are WJEC Eduqas-specific GCSE play texts produced in partnership with Globe Education.

### Pedagogical Approaches and Focus Areas

The major areas of focus when teaching Romeo and Juliet include: (1) decoding and comprehending Shakespeare's archaic language and (2) comparing his original text to other works that have drawn on his original text.

This end-of-year unit draws upon literary analysis and writing skills students have been developing throughout the year and applies them to Shakespeare's complex language and style. While students may have previously read simplified versions, this is often their first experience with Shakespeare's original, more archaic language.

### Educational Resources and Materials

CommonLit offers thousands of lessons, a full-year ELA curriculum, and has created Book Pairings for over a hundred classic books taught in schools across the country. The lessons in Book Pairings are designed to build students' reading comprehension and engagement, with every pairing including information about the new text and discussion questions.

The Royal Shakespeare Company provides information and resources for teachers and learners on Romeo and Juliet.

### Academic Skills Development

The curriculum emphasizes building skills described in Common Core ELA standard RL.9-10.9, "analyzing how an author draws on and transforms source material." Students analyze works by fourteenth-century poet Petrarch, investigating how Shakespeare drew on Petrarch's themes and characters.

Students also engage with modern adaptations, watching pieces of the 1996 Baz Luhrmann film version and reading excerpts from Walter Dean Myers' novel "Street Love," analyzing how these modern artists transform Shakespeare's sixteenth-century play.

### Classroom Considerations

Romeo and Juliet features teenage suicide, a topic that can be difficult to address in a classroom setting, requiring careful pedagogical consideration.

The play remains a cornerstone of English literature education globally, with educational publishers and institutions providing specialized materials and approaches to make Shakespeare's work accessible to students across different educational systems and grade levels.
